data.text: Contents

Role & Responsibilities within the Trust ........................................................................ 4  Standard Operating Procedure for Oximetry at home for COVID patients .................... 6
Introduction

This document is to provide a standard operating procedure for patients with COVID-19 who can be safely monitored at home. The use of home oximetry monitoring empowers patients to self-monitor, detect and act on early deterioration in COVID to hopefully reduce complications. Home monitoring will also facilitate early supported discharge and/or admission avoidance. It has been produced in line with NHS England and NHS Improvement requirement to deliver COVID virtual wards as set out in https://www.england.nhs.uk/coronavirus/publication/covid- virtual-ward/
Scope
The purpose of this document is to provide guidance on the safe procedure for patients monitored at home using pulse oximetry.
Not in scope:
Discharge of patients with Covid Oximetry at home with oxygen will be managed through Virtual ward -Hospital at Home/Community services and not included in this SOP.
Definitions
Role and responsibilities within the Trust

The MSE Patient Safety and Quality Group is responsible for ensuring the trust is providing a high quality service, monitor and review the quality of services and be responsible to significant patient safety risks.
Site Medical Director:

Each Site Medical Director is responsible for ensuring that the necessary systems, processes, training and competency assessment (where appropriate) are available to ensure that all medical and dental staff are able to comply with the contents of this document. In addition, he/she is responsible for ensuring that the monitoring and audit of this document is undertaken and reported in the appropriate forum as indicated in the document.
4.2.1 Site Director of Nursing:

Each Site Director of Nursing is responsible for ensuring that the necessary systems, processes, training and competency assessment (where appropriate) are available to ensure that all non-medical staff (nurses, midwives and allied health professionals) are able to comply with the contents of this document.
4.2.2 Director of Operations for Care Group 1:

The Director of Operations for Care Group 1 is responsible for ensuring that the systems and processes are disseminated appropriately and compliance is adhered to in conjunction with the site Directors of Operations.
4.2.3 Directorate/Divisional Clinical Directors:

The Directorate/Divisional Clinical Directors are responsible for ensuring that systems and processes are in place throughout the Directorates/Divisions to ensure that this document is disseminated appropriately and that monitoring of compliance is undertaken, with remedial action implemented as appropriate. In addition, the Directorate/Divisional Clinical Directors are responsible for ensuring that all medical and dental staff comply with the contents of the document.
4.2.4 Directorate/Divisional General Managers/Associate Directors

The Divisional General Managers are responsible for implementing the systems and processes required throughout the Divisions to ensure that this document is disseminated appropriately and that monitoring of compliance is undertaken, with remedial action implemented as appropriate.
4.2.5 Directorate/Divisional Heads of Nursing and Quality (HoNQ):
The HoNQs are responsible for ensuring that the policy is disseminated throughout the Division and that the required monitoring and audit are undertaken, with the resources provided to support this.
4.2.6 Emergency Department Medical Staff
The  Emergency Department clinical leads are responsible for ensuring all members of the ED team are aware of this SOP and follow its procedures.
4.2.7 Respiratory leads
The site respiratory clinical lead is responsible for disseminating this SOP and ensuring clinicians are the back door/ early supported discharge element of this SOP is adhered to
4.2.8 Nursing Staff

The nurse in charge is accountable for the safe care and management of patient on the pathway. They are therefore responsible for ensuring that all staff within the ward comply with this document and for implementing a system to provide assurance that this is the case.
Standard operating procedure for oximetry at home for covid
patients

Pathways, referral form, care pathway documentation, remote monitoring diary and internal process diagrams can be found in the appendices of this SOP. Some operationalising of this SOP will differ slightly due to site variances, but the main purpose and process remains consistent, as per this body of this SOP.
Patient Identification:
Patients from EDs, Acute Medical Units (AMUs), or Same Day Emergency Care (SDEC) with confirmed or suspected COVID can be enrolled using the pathways (Pathway 1a).

5.2.1  Patients meeting the criteria can also be enrolled from the COVID wards for early supported discharge  (Pathway 1b). Both pathways will manage patients in the same way; the only difference is the entry point to the pathway. All such patients will need to be reviewed by a Medical SpR/Middle Grade/Consultant to ensure suitability. Significant cognitive impairment should be a contraindication.
Enrolment Procedure:
Patients need to be given a pack including a pulse oximeter, diary or registered with My Health Covid, patient information sheet, and contact details for SDEC at each site. They can be contacted via:
Basildon:
Email: MedAmbulatoryCare@btuh.nhs.uk  Extension 8404/8402.
Broomfield:
Email: Ambulatory.Care@meht.nhs.uk Extension:3207/3208
Southend:
Email: medical.navigators@southend.nhs.uk Extension: 7292/8817

5.3.1  The patient information leaflet (see Appendix 4) will need to be updated on page 3 with target oxygen sats ranges for that particular patient. Recommended levels for calling 999 would be <85% for lower target range or <88% for higher target range patients. Recommended levels for non-urgent advice would be  for lower target patients and <89% for higher target range patients.
Telephone follow up:
Calls need to be planned for days 2, 5, 7, 10, 12, 14 from onset of symptoms and adjusted if necessary based on the follow up flow chart.
Check you have correct patient using 3 identifiers (First name, Surname, DoB)
Explain who you are and that you are calling to gather readings and check progress with symptoms
End call with safety netting script, reiterating patient-initiated escalation routes via numbers found in their diary & advice of next scheduled monitoring call

If symptoms/readings worse or new symptoms volunteered, end call with advice of escalation action to be taken as appropriate (see follow up flow chart). Escalate where necessary to the appropriate escalation route stated in the flow chart
Discuss case with Ambulatory care doctor should you be unsure of actions to take
Three attempts should be made to contact patient. Non-contactable patients should be escalated to the Ambulatory care doctor for action to take
At any point advice from the Respiratory Consultant on call can be sought.

5.4.1  If the patient is in scenario 1 (follow-up flow chart) on day 14 from symptom onset, invite to SDEC for final review, return of pulse oximeter, discharge and book 6 week X-ray and TCI appointment to review outcome.
Safety netting script to say at the end of the call:
MAKE YOUR WAY TO ACCIDENT AND EMERGENCY IMMEDIATELY, OR IF YOU ARE UNABLE TO DO SO, RING 999 if:
Your oxygen level is _____ or below (target saturations as agreed)
Your heart rate is 130 or above
You are unable to complete short sentences at rest due to breathlessness
You develop chest pain
Your breathing suddenly worsens
You are coughing up blood
You have blue lips or a blue face
You feel cold and sweaty with pale or blotchy skin
You collapse or faint
You become agitated, confused or very drowsy
You have stopped peeing or are peeing much less than usual
Otherwise If you are concerned in any other way about your please contact the number on your diary sheet for advice
Training requirements
No specific training requirements.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the MSE Clinical Advisory Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the clinical teams of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 11)
References
This should list any documents that have been specifically been referred to in the text of the policy – just type over this text.

data.text: Appendix 4: Remote monitoring COVID-19 diary
Basildon

data.url: MSESOP-21004 Oximetry at home for COVID patients 1.0.032.png

data.text: Remote monitoring COVID-19 diary
Pulse oximeter for heart rate and blood oxygen level

Your doctor has given you, or your carer, this diary and pulse oximeter because you have symptoms of COVID-19. A pulse oximeter helps you monitor how fast your heart is beating and the level of oxygen in your blood. Blood oxygen level is

data.url: MSESOP-21004 Oximetry at home for COVID patients 1.0.034.png

data.text: the most accurate way of keeping an eye on your progress  with  COVID-19.  An  ideal  blood  oxygen level is between 95% and 99%. An ideal heart rate is between  and 90 beats per minute (bpm).
How to use a pulse oximeter
Follow these instructions to make sure the pulse oximeter gives an accurate reading
Remove any nail polish or false nails and warm your hand if cold.
Make sure you have been resting for at least five minutes before taking your measurement.
Rest your hand on your chest at heart level and hold still.
Switch the pulse oximeter on and place it on your finger. It works best on your middle or index finger (see diagram). It should not be used on your ear.
The reading takes time to steady. Keep the pulse oximeter in place for at least a minute, or longer if the reading keeps changing.
Record the highest result once the reading has not changed for five seconds.
Be careful to identify which reading is your heart rate and which is your oxygen level.
You can also watch an NHS YouTube video on how to use a pulse oximeter.
Recording and acting on the results
Record your results in the diary below.

Your first measurement is your baseline – so record this in the highlighted area. Then take recordings three times a day, at the same time each day – for example when you normally eat in the morning, at lunchtime and in the evening. Take extra measurements if you feel there has been a change in your health. Please also record changes in how you are feeling and your breathing.

Keep track of your temperature if you can. However, as long as your oxygen level and breathing are normal, you do not need to contact the Ambulatory Care Unit/NHS  if you have a temperature or other symptoms, such as cough, muscle aches, tiredness and change in taste or smell. Paracetamol and regular fluids can help with these symptoms, and most people will get better by themselves within two to three weeks. Please see the NHS website for information on self- isolation or how to access care.

You will be contacted by a member of the Medical Ambulatory Care Team at regular intervals (at day 2, 5, 7, 10,  and 14) who will take details of your symptoms and oxygen levels, and advise if any further action needs to be taken. After 14 days, if you have improved, monitoring will no longer be required, and you will be asked to attend Ambulatory Care to check all is well before final discharge.
What to do if you experience the following symptoms:
Attend your nearest A&E or call 999 immediately if you have one or more of the following and tell the operator you may have coronavirus:

data.url: MSESOP-21004 Oximetry at home for COVID patients 1.0.035.png

data.text: You are unable to complete short sentences when at rest due to breathlessness.
Your breathing suddenly worsens.
Your blood oxygen level is _____ or less. Check your blood oxygen level again straight away – if it's still _____ or below, go to A&E immediately or call 999
OR if these more general signs of serious illness develop:
you are coughing up blood
you feel cold and sweaty with pale or blotchy skin
you develop a rash that does not fade when you roll a drinking glass over it
you collapse or faint
you become agitated, confused or very drowsy
you have stopped peeing or are peeing much less than usual.
If you have a pulse oximeter, please give the oxygen saturation reading to the  operator.
Telephone Ambulatory Care 10am to 6pm (Basildon Hospital 01268 524900 x 8404 or 8402) or 111 at other times if you have one or more of the following and tell the operator you may have coronavirus:

data.url: MSESOP-21004 Oximetry at home for COVID patients 1.0.036.png

data.text: You slowly start feeling more unwell or more breathless.
You are having difficulty breathing when getting up to go to the toilet or similar.
If you use a pulse oximeter, your blood oxygen level is ______ or when sitting or lying down, and remains at this level after being rechecked within an hour.
You sense that something is wrong (general weakness, extreme tiredness, loss of appetite, reduced urine output, unable to care for yourself – simple tasks like washing and dressing or making food).
MSE Oximetry at home for covid patients / MSESOP-21004/ 1.0
Page  of
Family and friends checking you are safe

It is important that someone checks on you regularly. If you are isolating from other people in the same house as you, talking on your phone or through a doorway could be better than sending text messages. It will help them hear if you are becoming more breathless or unwell. If you live alone, you should arrange to contact someone regularly. Ask them to ring you if you don't contact them as planned and ask them to seek help if you don't answer.
If you are still unwell after three weeks, please contact your GP.
Returning the pulse oximeter

When you no longer need the device, please return it to the Ambulatory Care Unit. If you are shielding please ask a friend or volunteer to do this for you. You should return it in the bag provided so that it can be safely cleaned and given to other patients.

You are likely to have it for  days from the onset of your illness. We do see some patients who feel unwell again after the first week of symptoms, so please keep the oximeter until the full 14 days have passed.
Please return the diary along with the pulse oximeter so you can help the NHS learn how best to help other patients with COVID-19.
Page  of

data.text: MSE NHS Trust Version
This is suggested content for a COVID-19 diary that patients could use under clinical supervision to support remote monitoring of patients with confirmed or possible COVID-19.
Pulse oximeter for heart rate and blood oxygen level

Your doctor has given you, or your carer, this diary and pulse oximeter because you have symptoms of COVID-19. A pulse oximeter helps you monitor how fast your heart is beating and the level of oxygen in your blood. Blood oxygen level is

data.url: MSESOP-21004 Oximetry at home for COVID patients 1.0.034.png

data.text: the most accurate way of keeping an eye on your progress  with COVID-19. An ideal blood oxygen level is between 95%  and 99%. An ideal heart rate is between 50 and 90 beats per  minute (bpm).
How to use a pulse oximeter
Follow  these instructions  to  make  sure  the  pulse  oximeter  gives  an  accurate  reading (diagram to right courtesy of Denis Barbulat):
Remove any nail polish or false nails and warm your hand if cold.
Make sure you have been resting for at least five minutes before taking your measurement.
Rest your hand on your chest at heart level and hold still.
Switch the pulse oximeter on and place it on your finger. It works best on your middle or index finger (see diagram). It should not be used on your ear.
The reading takes time to steady. Keep the pulse oximeter in place for at least a minute, or longer if the reading keeps changing.
Record the highest result once the reading has not changed for five seconds.
Be careful to identify which reading is your heart rate and which is your oxygen level.
You can also watch an NHS YouTube video on how to use a pulse oximeter.

data.url: MSESOP-21004 Oximetry at home for COVID patients 1.0.038.png

data.text: Decontamination: If you are handling equipment or items (e.g. pulse oximeters) used on/by patients with suspected COVID-19, then please wash your hands carefully after touching the equipment, and if being used on different patients then ensure that it is cleaned between each patient, following the published guidance.
Recording and acting on the results
Record your results in the diary below.

Your first measurement is your baseline – so record this in the highlighted blue area. Then take recordings three times a day, at the same time each day – for example when you normally eat in the morning, at lunchtime and in the evening. Take extra measurements if you feel there has been a change in your health. Please also record changes in how you are feeling and your breathing.

Keep track of your temperature if you can. However, as long as your oxygen level and breathing are normal, you do not need to contact the Ambulatory Care Unit/NHS 111 if you have a temperature or other symptoms, such as cough, muscle aches, tiredness and change in taste or smell. Paracetamol and regular fluids can help with these symptoms, and most people will get better by themselves within two to three weeks. Please see the NHS website for information on self-isolation or how to access care.

You will be contacted by telephone by a member of the Ambulatory Care Team at regular intervals who will take details of your symptoms and oxygen levels, and advise if any further action needs to be taken. After 14 days, if you have improved, monitoring will no longer be required, and you will be asked to attend Ambulatory Care to check all is well before final discharge.
https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/877533/Rout ine_decontamination_of_reusable_noninvasive_equipment.pdf

Returning the pulse oximeter

When you no longer need the device, please return it to the Ambulatory Care Unit. If you are shielding please ask a friend or volunteer to do this for you. You should return it in the bag provided so that it can be safely cleaned and given to other patients.

You are likely to have it for  days from the onset of your illness. We do see some patients who feel unwell again after the first week of symptoms, so please keep the oximeter until the full 14 days have passed.
Please return the diary along with the pulse oximeter so you can help the NHS learn how best to help other patients with COVID-19.

Admit to pathway and book TCI follow up calls [on Medway/Lorenzo]. Give patient pack including pulse oximeter, Remote Monitoring Diary or registered with My Health Covid, patient information leaflet and Ambulatory care contact details:

data.text: days from symptoms  later the same day,
to  be  reviewed  for  or  face  to  face
final discharge  review.  If  stable,
review following day

Review at day 14. Either discharge, readmit to pathway for continued follow up or admit to hospital. If discharging, invite back to Ambulatory care for final review with SDEC clinician and return of oximeter. Discharge letter sent to GP and 6 week X-ray and TCI appointment booked to review outcome.

data.url: MSESOP-21004 Oximetry at home for COVID patients 1.0.060.png

data.text: COVID Oximetry at Home –telephone call suggested script
Calls to be planned for days 2, 5, 7, 10, 12, 14 from onset of symptoms, and adjusted if necessary based on the follow up flow chart.
Check you have correct patient using 3 identifiers (First name, Surname, DoB)
Explain who you are and that you are calling to gather readings and check progress with symptoms
End call with safety netting script, reiterating patient-initiated escalation routes via numbers found in their diary & advice of next scheduled monitoring call

If symptoms/readings worse or new symptoms volunteered, end call with advice of escalation action to be taken as appropriate (see follow up flow chart). Escalate where necessary to the appropriate escalation route stated in the flow chart
Discuss case with Ambulatory care doctor should you be unsure of actions to take
Three attempts should be made to contact patient. Non-contactable patients should be escalated to the Ambulatory care doctor for action to take
At any point advice from the Respiratory Consultant on call can be sought.
Safety netting script to say at the end of the call:
MAKE YOUR WAY TO ACCIDENT AND EMERGENCY IMMEDIATELY, OR IF YOU ARE UNABLE TO DO SO, RING 999 if:
Your oxygen level is _____ or below
Your heart rate is 130 or above
You are unable to complete short sentences at rest due to breathlessness
You develop chest pain
Your breathing suddenly worsens
You are coughing up blood
You have blue lips or a blue face
You feel cold and sweaty with pale or blotchy skin
You collapse or faint
You become agitated, confused or very drowsy
You have stopped peeing or are peeing much less than usual
Otherwise If you are concerned in any other way about your please contact the number on your diary sheet for advice
MSE Oximetry at home for covid patients / MSESOP-21004/ 1.0

Appendix7: Preliminary equality analysis
This assessment relates to: MSE Oximetry at home for covid patients / MSESOP-21004 (Please tick all that apply)

table_items.text: ☐ A change in a service to patients
☐ A change to an existing document
☐ A change to the way staff work
What are you proposing to change?
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)
To provide a safe pathway to monitor patients with COVID-19 out of the acute Trust if appropriate
Who benefits from this change and how?
Patient flow within the Trust is benefitted by freeing up beds. Patients are benefitted by recovering in their own environment, improving comfort infection control risk.
Is anyone likely to suffer any negative impact as a result of this change? If no, please record reasons here and sign and date this assessment. If yes, please complete a full EIA.
a) Will you be undertaking any consultation as part of this change?
